original: paramattho, tato so puggalo upalabbhati saccikaṭṭhaparamatthenāti, na hevaṃ vattabbe.
analyzed: paramatthaḥ tatas saḥ puggalaḥ upalabbhati saccikaṭṭha paramatthena ati na ha evam vattabbe
translated: “Is that person found in an ultimate sense as a reality in the ultimate sense that is other than form, etc.,” — “That is not so.”

original: Ājānāhi niggahaṃ hañci puggalo upalabbhati saccikaṭṭhaparamatthena, tena vata re
analyzed: ājānāhi niggaham hañci puggalaḥ upalabbhati saccikaṭṭha paramatthena tena vata re
translated: Do you admit that you are refuted? Then you must

original: vattabbe “yo saccikaṭṭho paramattho, tato so puggalo upalabbhati saccikaṭṭhaparamatthenā”ti.🔽Yaṃ tattha vadesi “vattabbe kho ‘puggalo upalabbhati saccikaṭṭhaparamatthena’, no
analyzed: vattabbe yaḥ saccikaṭṭhaḥ paramattho tatas saḥ puggalaḥ upalabbhati saccikaṭṭha paramatthena ati  yam tattha vadesi vattabbe kho puggalaḥ upalabbhati saccikaṭṭha paramatthena no
translated: say: ‘That which is real, ultimate fact, that is the person as real, ultimate fact.’🔽If you say: ‘The person is found as real, ultimate fact,

original: ca vattabbe ‘yo saccikaṭṭho paramattho, tato so puggalo upalabbhati saccikaṭṭhaparamatthenā”ti,
analyzed: ca vattabbe yaḥ saccikaṭṭhaḥ paramattho tatas saḥ puggalaḥ upalabbhati saccikaṭṭha paramatthena ati
translated: but you must not say: “That which is real, ultimate fact, that is the person as real, ultimate fact,”’🔽this is wrong.

original: micchāti evamādinā bhante tattha paṭhamā puggalakathā pañca bhāṇavāramattāya tantiyā
analyzed: micchā ti evamādinā bhante tattha paṭhamā puggala kathā pañca bhāṇa vāra mattāya tantiyā
translated: In this way, venerable sir, the first discussion of the person, in five sections, in five chapters,

original: āyasmatā mahāmoggaliputtatissattherena vitthārato vibhajitvā kathitā.
analyzed: ā yasmatā mahāmoggali putta tissa therena vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā kathitā
translated: was explained in detail by the venerable elder Mahā-Moggallāna.

original: Aññāṇakathā
analyzed: aññāṇa kathā
translated: The Discussion of Ignorance

original: Pucchā – abhidhammapiṭake āvuso kathāvatthuppakaraṇe dutiyavagge dutiyā aññāṇakathā āyasmatā mahāmoggaliputtatissattherena kathaṃ vitthārato vibhajitvā kathitā.
analyzed: pucchā abhidhamma piṭake āvuso kathā vatthu ppakaraṇe dutiya vagge dutiyā aññāṇa kathā āyasmatā mahāmoggaliputta tissa therena katham vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā kathitā
translated: Question: In the Kathāvatthu, the second book of the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, in the second chapter, in the second section, ‘The Discussion of Ignorance’, how did the elder Moggaliputta-tissa explain in detail?

original: Vissajjanā – abhidhammapiṭake bhante pañcame kathāvatthuppakaraṇe dutiyavagge dutiyā🔽aññāṇakathā “atthi arahato aññāṇanti, āmantā. Atthi arahato avijjā avijjogho avijjāyogo🔽avijjānusayo avijjāpariyuṭṭhānaṃ avijjāsaṃyojanaṃ avijjānīvaraṇanti, na hevaṃ vattabbe.🔽Natthi arahato avijjā avijjogho avijjāyogo avijjānusayo avijjāpariyuṭṭhānaṃ avijjāsaṃyojanaṃ
analyzed: vissajjanā abhidhammapiṭake bhante pañcame kathā vatthu ppakaraṇe dutiya vagge dutiyā  aññāṇa kathā atthi arahataḥ aññāṇanti āmantā atthi arahataḥ avijjā avijjoghaḥ avijjā yogo  avijjā anusayaḥ avijjā pariyuṭṭhānam avijjā saṃyojanam avijjā nīvaraṇam ti na ha evam vattabbe  natthi arahataḥ avijjā avijjā oghaḥ avijjā yogaḥ avijjā anusayaḥ avijjā pariyuṭṭhānam avijjā saṃyojanam
translated: The Releasing: in the Fifth Chapter of the Abhidhamma Piṭaka called the Book of the Aggregates, in the Second Section, the second

original: avijjānivaraṇanti, āmantā. Hañci natthi arahato avijjā avijjogho avijjāyogo avijjānusayo
analyzed: avijjā nivaraṇanti āmantā hañci natthi arahataḥ avijjā avijjoghaḥ avijjā yogo avijjā anusayo
translated: The Discussion of Non-knowing: “Is there any non-knowing in a perfected one? “—“Yes, venerable sir.” “Is there any ignorance, ignorance-flood, ignorance- shackle, ignorance-clinging, ignorance- hindrance, ignorance-obsession, ignorance- underlying-tendency, ignorance-perversion, ignorance-warp, ignorance-bond, ignorance-darkness, ignorance-blindness, ignorance-cover, ignorance-barrenness, ignorance-delusion, ignorance-bewilderment, ignorance-concealment, ignorance-obstruction, ignorance-obfuscation, ignorance-confusion, ignorance-delusion-obsession in a perfected one? “—“That is not so.”

original: avijjāpariyuṭṭhānaṃ avijjāsaṃyojanaṃ avijjānīvaraṇaṃ, no ca vata re vattabbe “atthi
analyzed: avijjā pariyuṭṭhānam avijjā saṃyojanam avijjā nīvaraṇam no ca vata re vattabbe atthi
translated: “Is there no ignorance, ignorance-flood, … ignorance-delusion-obsession in a perfected one? “—“Yes, venerable sir.” “Then it is not correct to say that there is any non-knowing in a perfected one.”

original: arahato aññāṇa”nti evamādinā āyasmatā mahāmoggaliputtatissattherena vitthārato vibhajitvā bhāsitā.
analyzed: arahataḥ evamādinā āyasmatā mahāmoggali putta tissa therena vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā bhāsitā
translated: Thus the venerable elder Mahā Moggallāna the Great explained in detail.

original: Asaññakathā
analyzed: asañña kathā
translated: The Discussion of Non-percipient Beings

original: Pucchā – abhidhammapiṭake āvuso pañcame kathāvatthuppakaraṇe tatiyavagge ekādasamā asaññakathā āyasmatā mahāmoggaliputtatissattherena kathaṃ vitthārato vibhajitvā kathitā.
analyzed: pucchā abhidhamma piṭake āvuso pañcame kathā vatthu ppakaraṇe tatiya vagge ekādasamā asañña kathā āyasmatā mahāmoggali putta tissa therena katham vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā kathitā
translated: Question – Now, in the fifth book of the Abhidhamma called the Kathāvatthu, in the third chapter called “On the Non-percipient Beings,” the venerable Elder Moggaliputtatissa has analyzed and explained the eleventh question.

original: Vissajjanā – abhidhammapiṭake bhante pañcame kathāvatthuppakaraṇe tatiyavagge ekādasamā🔽asaññakathā “asaññasattesu saññā atthīti, āmantā. Saññābhavo saññāgati saññāsattāvāso
analyzed: vissajjanā abhidhammapiṭake bhante pañcame kathā vatthu ppakaraṇe tatiya vagge ekādasamā  asañña kathā asañña sattesu saññā atthi iti āmantā saññā bhavaḥ saññā gati saññā sattā vāso
translated: Answer – In the fifth book of the Abhidhamma called the Kathāvatthu, in the third chapter called “On the Non-percipient Beings,” the venerable Elder Moggaliputtatissa has analyzed and explained the eleventh question.

original: saññāsaṃsāro saññāyoni saññattabhāvapaṭilābhoti, na hevaṃ vattabbe”ti evamādinā āyasmatā🔽mahāmoggaliputtatissattherena vitthārato vibhajitvā kathitā.
analyzed: saññā saṃsāro saññā yoni saññatta bhāva paṭilābho ti na ha ivam vattabbā iti evamādinā āyasmatā  mahāmoggali putta tissa ttherena vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā kathitā
translated: “In the case of non-percipient beings, there is perception, teacher.” “There is a state of perception, a destiny of perception, a realm of perception, a sphere of perception, a rebirth in perception, a reappearance in perception, a manifestation of a selfhood in perception.” “That cannot be maintained.”

original: Asaññasattesu saññā atthi.
analyzed: asañña sattesu saññā atthi
translated: In the case of non-percipient beings, there is perception.

original: Saññābhavo saññāgati saññāsattāvāso saññāsaṃsāro saññāyoni saññattabhāvapaṭilābho.
analyzed: saññā bhavaḥ saññā gati saññā sattā vāso saññā saṃsāro saññā yoni saññatta bhāva paṭilābho
translated: There is a state of perception, a destiny of perception, a realm of perception, a sphere of perception, a rebirth in perception, a reappearance in perception, a manifestation of a selfhood in perception.

original: Na hevaṃ vattabbe.
analyzed: na ha ivam vattabbe
translated: That cannot be maintained.

original: Nanu asaññabhavo asaññagati asaññasattāvāso asaññasaṃsāro asaññayoni asaññattabhāvapaṭilābho.
analyzed: nanu asañña bhavaḥ asañña gati asañña sattā vāsaḥ asañña saṃsāraḥ asañña yoni asaññatta bhāva paṭilābhaḥ
translated: Isn’t the non-percipient realm a realm, a destination, a place of rebirth, a destiny, a sphere of existence, a mode of life, a rebirth-linking?

original: Hañci asaññabhavo asaññagati asaññasattāvāso asaññasaṃsāro asaññayoni asaññattabhāvapaṭilābho, no ca vata re vattabbe asaññasattesu saññā atthi.
analyzed: hañci asañña bhavaḥ asañña gati asañña sattā vāsaḥ asañña saṃsāraḥ asañña yoni a saññatta bhāva paṭilābho no ca vata re vattabbe asañña sattesu saññā atthi
translated: If the non-percipient realm is a realm, a destination, a place of rebirth, a destiny, a sphere of existence, a mode of life, a rebirth-linking, then it is not right to say that there is perception in the non-percipient beings.

original: Asaññasattesu saññā atthi.
analyzed: asañña sattesu saññā atthi
translated: There is perception in the non-percipient beings.

original: Pañcavokārabhavo gati sattāvāso saṃsāro yoni attabhāvapaṭilābho.
analyzed: pañcavokāra bhavaḥ gati sattā vāsaḥ saṃsāraḥ yoni atta bhāva paṭilābhaḥ
translated: The five-constituent realm is a realm, a destination, a place of rebirth, a destiny, a sphere of existence, a mode of life, a rebirth-linking.

original: Nanu ekavokārabhavo gati sattāvāso saṃsāro yoni attabhāvapaṭilābho.
analyzed: nanu ekavokāra bhavaḥ gati sattā vāsaḥ saṃsāraḥ yoni atta bhāva paṭilābhaḥ
translated: Isn’t the one-constituent realm a realm, a destination, a place of rebirth, a destiny, a sphere of existence, a mode of life, a rebirth-linking?

original: Hañci ekavokārabhavo gati sattāvāso saṃsāro yoni attabhāvapaṭilābho, no ca vata re vattabbe asaññasattesu saññā atthi.
analyzed: ekavokāra bhavaḥ gati sattā vāso saṃsāraḥ yoni atta bhāva paṭilābho no ca vata re vattabbe asañña sattesu saññā atthi
translated: If the one-constituent realm is a realm, a destination, a place of rebirth, a destiny, a sphere of existence, a mode of life, a rebirth-linking, then it is not right to say that there is perception in the non-percipient beings.

original: Chaṭṭhavagga
analyzed: chaṭṭha vagga
translated: The Sixth Division

original: Pathavīdhātusanidassanātiādikathā
analyzed: pathavī dhātu sani dassana ati ādi kathā
translated: The Discussion of the Earth Element, etc.

original: Pucchā – chaṭṭhavagge pana āvuso aṭṭhamā pathavīdhātu sanidassanātiādikathā āyasmatā mahāmoggaliputtatissattherena kathaṃ vitthārato vibhajitvā kathitā.
analyzed: pucchā chaṭṭha vagge pana āvuso aṭṭhamā pathavī dhātu sanidassanā ati ādi kathā āyasmatā mahāmoggaliputta tissa therena katham vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā kathitā
translated: Question: But, friend, how was the explanation given by the venerable elder Mahā-Moggallāna-tissa in the sixth chapter, beginning with the question, “Is the eighth earth-element visible?”🔽Answer: In the sixth chapter, venerable sir, the explanation of the question, “Is the eighth earth-element visible?”

original: Vissajjanā – chaṭṭhavagge bhante aṭṭhamā pathavīdhātu sanidassanātiādikathā “pathavīdhātu
analyzed: vissajjanā chaṭṭha vagge bhante aṭṭhamā pathavī dhātu pathavī dhātu
translated: was given in detail by the elder Mahā-Moggallāna-tissa as follows: “The earth-element

original: sanidassanāti āmantā. Rūpaṃ rūpāyatanaṃ rūpadhātu nīlaṃ pītakaṃ lohitakaṃ odātaṃ
analyzed: āmantā rūpam rūpa āyatanam rūpa dhātu nīlam pītakam lohitakam odātam
translated: is visible. The visible form, the visible form base, the visible form element, the blue, the yellow, the red, the white,

original: cakkhuviññeyyaṃ cakkhusmiṃ paṭihaññati cakkhussa āpāthaṃ āgacchatīti, na hevaṃ vattabbe”ti🔽evamādinā āyasmatā mahāmoggali puttatissattherena vitthārato vibhajitvā kathitā.
analyzed: cakkhu viññeyyam cakkhusmim paṭihaññati cakkhussa āpātham āgacchati iti na ha evam vattabbā iti  evamādinā ā yasmatā mahāmoggali putta tissa therena vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā kathitā
translated: what is cognizable by the eye, what strikes the eye, what comes within the eye’s range—it is not proper to say that.”

original: Pathavīdhātu sanidassanā.
analyzed: pathavī dhātu sani dassanā
translated: The earth-element is visible.

original: Cakkhuñca paṭicca pathavīdhātuñca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ.
analyzed: cakkhuñca paṭicca pathavī dhātuñca uppajjati cakkhu viññāṇam
translated: Eye-consciousness arises in dependence on the eye and the earth-element.

original: Tena hi na vattabbaṃ cakkhuñca paṭicca pathavīdhātuñca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ.
analyzed: tena hi na vattabbam cakkhuñca paṭicca pathavī dhātuñca uppajjati cakkhu viññāṇam
translated: Therefore it is not proper to say that eye-consciousness arises in dependence on the eye and the earth-element.

original: Antarābhavakathā
analyzed: antarābhava kathā
translated: The Discussion of the Intermediate State

original: Pucchā – abhidhammapiṭake āvuso pañcame kathāvatthuppakaraṇe aṭṭhamavagge dutiyā antarābhavakathā āyasmatā mahāmoggaliputtatissattherena kathaṃ vitthārato vibhajitvā kathitā.
analyzed: pucchā abhidhamma piṭake āvuso pañcame kathā vatthu ppakaraṇe aṭṭhama vagge dutiyā antarābhava kathā āyasmatā mahāmoggaliputta tissa therena katham vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā kathitā
translated: Question – In the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, venerable sir, in the fifth book called the Kathāvatthu, in the eighth chapter called “The Discussion of the Intermediate State,” how did the Elder Tissa, the Great Moggaliputta, explain the second question on the intermediate state?

original: Vissajjanā – abhidhammapiṭake bhante pañcame kathāvatthuppakaraṇe aṭṭhamavagge dutiyā🔽antarābhavakathā “atthi antarābhavoti, āmantā. Kāmabhavoti, na hevaṃ vattabbe…pe…
analyzed: vissajjanā abhidhamma piṭake bhante pañcame kathā vatthu ppakaraṇe aṭṭhama vagge dutiyā  antarābhava kathā atthi antarābhavaḥ ti āmantā kāma bhavaḥ ti na ha ivam vattabbe pe
translated: Answer – In the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, venerable sir, in the fifth book called the Kathāvatthu, in the eighth chapter called “The Discussion of the Intermediate State,” the second question on the intermediate state was explained by the Elder Tissa, the Great Moggaliputta, in detail as follows:🔽“Is there an intermediate state? Yes, friend. Is it a sensual-sphere existence? That cannot be said. …

original: atthi antarābhavoti, āmantā. Rūpabhavoti, na hevaṃ vattabbe…pe… atthi antarābhavoti,🔽āmantā. Arūpabhavoti, na hevaṃ vattabbe”ti evamādinā āyasmatā mahāmoggaliputtatissattherena
analyzed: atthi antarābhavo ti āmantā rūpa bhavo ti na ha ivam vattabbā īpe atthi antarābhavo ti  āmantā arūpa bhavā ti na ha ivam vattabbā iti evamādinā āyasmatā mahāmoggaliputta tissa therena
translated: Is there an intermediate state? Yes, friend. Is it a fine-material-sphere existence? That cannot be said. … Is there an intermediate state? Yes, friend. Is it an immaterial-sphere existence? That cannot be said. …

original: vitthārato vibhajitvā kathitā.
analyzed: vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā kathitā
translated: In this way, venerable sir, the Elder Tissa, the Great Moggaliputta, explained the second question on the intermediate state in detail.

original: Atthi antarābhavo.
analyzed: atthi antarābhavaḥ
translated: Is there an intermediate state?

original: Na hevaṃ vattabbe.
analyzed: na ha ivam vattabbe
translated: That cannot be said.

original: Atthi antarābhavo.
analyzed: atthi antarābhavaḥ
translated: Is there an intermediate state?

original: Kāmabhavassa ca rūpabhavassa ca antare atthi antarābhavo.
analyzed: kāma bhavassa ca rūpa bhavassa ca antare atthi antarābhavaḥ
translated: Is there an intermediate state between sensual-sphere existence and fine-material-sphere existence?

original: Na hevaṃ vattabbe.
analyzed: na ha ivam vattabbe
translated: That cannot be said.

original: Rūpabhavassa ca arūpabhavassa ca antare atthi antarābhavo.🔽Kāmabhavassa ca rūpabhavassa ca antare natthi antarābhavo.
analyzed: rūpa bhavassa ca arūpa bhavassa ca antare atthi antarābhavaḥ  kāma bhavassa ca rūpa bhavassa ca antare natthi antarābhavaḥ
translated: And there is a between-existence between the fine-material becoming and the immaterial becoming.

original: Hañci kāmabhavassa ca rūpabhavassa ca antare natthi antarābhavo, no ca vata re vattabbe atthi antarābhavo.
analyzed: hañci kāma bhavassa ca rūpa bhavassa ca antare natthi antarābhavaḥ no ca vata re vattabbe atthi antarābhavaḥ
translated: But there is no between-existence between the sensual-desire becoming and the fine-material becoming.🔽If you admit the latter, you will have to admit the former too.

original: Saḷāyatanuppattikathā
analyzed: saṅgāyatana uppatti kathā
translated: Discussion of the Appearance of the Sixfold Base

original: Pucchā – abhidhammapiṭake āvuso pañcame kathāvatthuppakaraṇe cuddasamavagge dutiyā saḷāyatanuppattikathā āyasmatā mahāmoggaliputtatissattherena kathaṃ vitthārato vibhajitvā desitā.
analyzed: pucchā abhidhamma piṭake āvuso pañcame kathā vatthu ppakaraṇe cuddasama vagge dutiyā saḷāyatana uppatti kathā āyasmatā mahāmoggaliputta tissa therena katham vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitā
translated: Question: Venerable sir, in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, in the fifth section of the Kathāvatthu, in the fourteenth chapter, “On the Appearance of the Sixfold Base,” the Elder Tissa, the Great Elder Moggaliputta’s pupil, teaches the doctrine by analyzing it in detail.

original: Vissajjanā – abhidhammapiṭake bhante pañcame kathāvatthuppakaraṇe cuddasamevagge🔽dutiyā saḷāyatanuppattikathā “saḷāyatanaṃ apubbaṃ acarimaṃ mātukucchismiṃ saṇṭhātīti,
analyzed: vissajjanā abhidhamma piṭake bhante pañcame kathā vatthu ppakaraṇe cuddasame vagge  dutiyā saḷāyatana uppatti kathā saḷāyatanam apubbam acarimam mātukucchismim saṇṭhāti iti
translated: Answer: In the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, venerable sir, in the fifth section of the Kathāvatthu, in the fourteenth chapter,🔽“On the Appearance of the Sixfold Base,” the Elder Tissa teaches the doctrine by analyzing it in detail in this way: “The sixfold base appears in the mother’s womb neither before nor after the appearance of the faculties” .

original: āmantā. Sabbaṅgapaccaṅgī ahīnindriyo mātukucchismiṃ okkamatīti, na hevaṃ vattabbe”ti
analyzed: āmantā sabbaṅga paccaṅgī ahīna indriyaḥ mātukucchismim okkamati iti na ha evam vattabbā iti
translated: “Is it true that the sixfold base appears in the mother’s womb neither before nor after the appearance of the faculties?”🔽“No, friend, that is not what I said.”

original: evamādinā āyasmatā mahāmoggaliputtatissattherena vitthārato vibhajitvā kathitā.
analyzed: evamādinā ā yasmatā mahāmoggali putta tissa ttherena vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā kathitā
translated: and so on. It was expounded in detail by the venerable elder Mahā Moggaliputta Tissa.

original: Saḷāyatanaṃ apubbaṃ acarimaṃ mātukucchismiṃ saṇṭhāti.
analyzed: saḷāyatanam apubbam acarimam mātukucchismim saṇṭhāti
translated: The six bases of contact are formed in the mother’s womb neither before nor after the being to be reborn.

original: Sabbaṅgappaccaṅgī ahīnindriyo mātukucchismiṃ okkamati.
analyzed: sabbaṅga ppaccaṅgī ahīn indriyaḥ mātukucchismim okkamati
translated: The being to be reborn enters the mother’s womb with all its limbs and faculties complete and not lacking any.

original: Na hevaṃ vattabbe.
analyzed: na ha ivam vattabbe
translated: That is not so.

original: Upapattesiyena cittena cakkhāyatanaṃ saṇṭhāti.
analyzed: upapattesiyena cittena cakkha āyatanam saṇṭhāti
translated: The eye base is formed by the rebirth-linking consciousness.

original: Upapattesiyena cittena hatthā saṇṭhanti, pādā saṇṭhanti, sīsaṃ saṇṭhāti, kaṇṇo saṇṭhāti, nāsikā saṇṭhāti, mukhaṃ saṇṭhāti, dantā saṇṭhanti.
analyzed: upapattesiyena cittena hatthāḥ saṇṭhanti pādāḥ saṇṭhanti sīsam saṇṭhāti kaṇṇaḥ saṇṭhāti nāsikā saṇṭhāti mukham saṇṭhāti dantāḥ saṇṭhanti
translated: The hand base is formed by the rebirth-linking consciousness, the foot base is formed by the rebirth-linking consciousness, the head base is formed by the rebirth-linking consciousness, the ear base is formed by the rebirth-linking consciousness, the nose base is formed by the rebirth-linking consciousness, the tongue base is formed by the rebirth-linking consciousness, the teeth base is formed by the rebirth-linking consciousness.

original: Na hevaṃ vattabbe.🔽Pucchā – tenāvuso bhagavatā yamakapāṭihīrāvasāne tāvatiṃsadevalokaṃ gantvā dasasahassalokadhātūhi
analyzed: na ha ivam vattabbe  pucchā tena āvuso bhagavatā yamaka pāṭihīra avasāne tāvatiṃsa deva lokam gantvā dasa sahassa lokadhātūhi
translated: That is not so.

original: āgamma sannisinnānaṃ devānaṃ abhidhammadesanaṃ desentena paṭhamaṃ abhidhammapiṭake
analyzed: āgamma sannisinnānam devānam abhidhamma desanam desentena paṭhamam abhidhamma piṭake
translated: Question: “Friend, by the Blessed One, after going to the Tāvatiṃsa world at the end of the Twin Miracle, having taught the Abhidhamma to the gods who had come from ten thousand world systems and were sitting together,🔽first in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka,

original: pañcappakaraṇāni desetvā tadanantaraṃ chaṭṭhaṃ yamakappakaraṇaṃ desentena kati yamakappakaraṇāni
analyzed: pañca ppakaraṇāni desetvā tad anantaram chaṭṭham yamaka pakaraṇam desentena kati yamaka ppakaraṇāni
translated: after teaching the five books, the sixth, the Yamaka Book, was taught. How many Yamaka Books were taught by him?

original: vibhajitvā desitāni.
analyzed: vibhajitvā desitāni
translated: and they were taught by analysis.

original: Vissajjanā – bhagavatā bhante yamassa visayātītena yamakapāṭihīrāvasāne tāvatiṃsadevalokaṃ
analyzed: vissajjanā bhagavatā bhante yamassa visaya atītena yamaka pāṭihīra avasāne tāvatiṃsa deva lokam
translated: The answer is this: The Blessed One, venerable sirs, having gone to the Tāvatiṃsa world after the Twin Miracle,

original: gantvā tattha dasasahassalokadhātūhi āgamma sannisinnānaṃ devatānaṃ abhidhammapiṭakaṃ
analyzed: gantvā tattha dasa sahassa lokadhātūhi āgamma sannisinnānam devatānam abhidhamma piṭakam
translated: and having taught the Abhidhamma Piṭaka there to the deities who had come from ten thousand world-systems,

original: desentena abhidhammapiṭake pūrimāni pañcappakaraṇāni desetvā tadanantaraṃ chaṭṭhaṃ🔽yamakappakaraṇaṃ mūlayamakaṃ khandhayamakaṃ āyatanayamakaṃ dhātuyamakaṃ saccayamakaṃ
analyzed: desentena abhidhamma piṭake pūrimāni pañca ppakaraṇāni desetvā tad anantaram chaṭṭham  yamaka ppakaraṇam mūlayamakam khandhayamakam āyatanayamakam dhātuyamakam saccayamakam
translated: and having taught the first five books of the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, he then taught the sixth book,🔽the Yamaka Book, in which there are ten books of the Yamaka, namely the Mūla-Yamaka, the Khandha-Yamaka, the Āyatana-Yamaka, the Dhātu-Yamaka, the Sacca-Yamaka,

original: saṅkhārayamakaṃ anusayayamakaṃ cittayamakaṃ dhammayamakaṃ indriyayamakanti dasa yamakappakaraṇāni
analyzed: saṅkhāra yamakam anusaya yamakam citta yamakam dhamma yamakam indriya yamakan ti dasa yamaka ppakaraṇāni
translated: the Saṅkhāra-Yamaka, the Anusaya-Yamaka, the Citta-Yamaka, the Dhamma-Yamaka, and the Indriya-Yamaka,

original: vitthārato vibhajitvā desitāni.
analyzed: vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitāni
translated: and they were taught by analysis in detail.

original: Mūlayamaka
analyzed: mūlayamaka
translated: The Mūla-Yamaka

original: Pucchā – kathañcāvuso tattha bhagavatā paṭhamaṃ mūlayamakaṃ vitthārato vibhajitvā desitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā kathañca āvuso tattha bhagavatā paṭhamam mūlayamakam vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitam
translated: “And how, friends, was the Mūla-Yamaka taught by analysis in detail by the Blessed One?

original: Vissajjanā – ye keci kusalā dhammā, sabbe te kusalamūlā. Ye vā pana kusalamūlā, sabbe
analyzed: vissajjanā ye keci kusalāḥ dhammāḥ sabbe te kusala mūlāḥ ye vā pana kusala mūlā sabbe
translated: The answer is this: Whatever are wholesome thoughts, are they all wholesome roots? Or, are those which are wholesome roots, are they all

original: te dhammā kusalā. Ye keci kusalā dhammā, sabbe te kusalamūlena ekamūlā. Ye vā pana🔽kusalamūlena ekamūlā, sabbe te dhammā kusalā. Ye keci kusalamūlena ekamūlā dhammā,
analyzed: te dhammā kusalā ye keci kusalāḥ dhammāḥ sabbe te kusala mūlena eka mūlāḥ ye vā pana  kusala mūlena eka mūlā sabbe te dhammā kusalā ye keci kusala mūlena eka mūlā dhammā
translated: These ideas are wholesome. Whatever are wholesome ideas, all of these are rooted in the wholesome. Or whatever are🔽rooted in the wholesome, all these ideas are wholesome. Whatever ideas are rooted in the wholesome,

original: sabbe te dhammā kusalamūlena aññamaññamūlā. Ye vā pana kusalamūlena aññamaññamūlā,
analyzed: sabbe te dhammā kusala mūlena aññamañña mūlāḥ ye vā pana kusala mūlena aññamañña mūlā
translated: all these ideas are rooted in the wholesome, one in another. Or whatever are rooted in the wholesome, one in another,

original: sabbe te dhammā kusalāti evamādinā bhante tattha bhagavatā paṭhamaṃ mūlayamakaṃ bāvīsatiyā
analyzed: sabbe te dhammā kusalā ti evamādinā bhante tattha bhagavatā paṭhamam mūlayamakam bāvīsatiyā
translated: all these ideas are wholesome. Thus, venerable sir, the first pair of roots was analysed by the Lord in the first place in detail with twenty-two triads and a hundred dyads,

original: ca tikehi dukasatena ca vitthārato vibhajitvā desitaṃ.
analyzed: ca tikehi duka satena ca vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitam
translated: and taught it.

original: Ye keci kusalā dhammā, sabbe te kusalamūlā.
analyzed: ye keci kusalāḥ dhammāḥ sabbe te kusala mūlā
translated: Whatever are wholesome ideas, all these are rooted in the wholesome.

original: Ye keci kusalā dhammā, sabbe te kusalamūlāti, tīṇeva kusalamūlāni avasesā kusalā dhammā, na kusalamūlā, ye vā pana kusalamūlā, sabbe te dhammā kusalāti, āmantā –
analyzed: ye keci kusalā dhammā sabbe te kusala mūlā ati tīṇi iva kusala mūlāni avasesā kusalāḥ dhammāḥ na kusala mūlā ye vā pana kusala mūlā sabbe te dhammā kusalā ati āmantā
translated: Whatever are wholesome ideas, all these are rooted in the wholesome, there are only three roots in the wholesome, and the remaining wholesome ideas are not roots in the wholesome, or whatever are roots in the wholesome, all these ideas are wholesome, and the venerable one said:

original: Khandhayamaka
analyzed: khandha yamaka
translated: The Dyad on the Categories

original: Pucchā – abhidhammapiṭake āvuso chaṭṭhe yamakappakaraṇe dutiyaṃ khandhayamakaṃ bhagavatā kathaṃ vitthārato vibhajitvā desitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā abhidhammapiṭake āvuso chaṭṭhe yamaka ppakaraṇe dutiyam khandha yamakam bhagavatā katham vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitam
translated: Question – In the sixth Compendium, the Book of Twos, in the second chapter on the Categories, how did the Blessed One teach the detailed explanation?

original: Vissajjanā – abhidhammapiṭake bhante chaṭṭhe yamakappakaraṇe dutiyaṃ khandhayamakaṃ
analyzed: vissajjanā abhidhammapiṭake bhante chaṭṭhe yamaka ppakaraṇe dutiyam khandha yamakam
translated: Answer – In the sixth Compendium, the Book of Twos, in the second chapter on the Categories,

original: “pañcakkhandhā – rūpakkhandho vedanākkhandho saññākkhandho saṅkhārakkhandho viññāṇakkhandho.
analyzed: pañca kkhandhāḥ rūpa kkhandhaḥ vedanā kkhandhaḥ saññā kkhandhaḥ saṅkhāra kkhandhaḥ viññāṇa kkhandhaḥ
translated: the Blessed One taught the detailed explanation as follows: “There are five categories: the form category, the feeling category, the perception category, the determinations category, and the consciousness category.

original: Rūpaṃ rūpakkhandho, rūpakkhandho rūpaṃ. Vedanā vedanākkhandho, vedanākkhandho vedanā.
analyzed: rūpam rūpa kkhandhaḥ rūpa kkhandhaḥ rūpam vedanā vedanā kkhandhaḥ vedanā kkhandhaḥ vedanā
translated: Form is the form category, the form category is form. Feeling is the feeling category, the feeling category is feeling.

original: Saññā saññākkhandho, saññākkhandho saññā. Saṅkhārā saṅkhārakkhandho, saṅkhārakkhandho
analyzed: saññā saññā kkhandhaḥ saññā kkhandhaḥ saññā saṅkhārā saṅkhāra kkhandhaḥ saṅkhāra kkhandhaḥ
translated: Perception is the perception category, the perception category is perception. Determinations are the determinations category, the determinations category is determinations.

original: saṅkhārā. Viññāṇaṃ viññāṇakkhandho, viññāṇakkhandho viññāṇa”nti evamādinā bhagavatā
analyzed: saṅkhārāḥ viññāṇam viññāṇa kkhandhaḥ viññāṇa kkhandhaḥ viññāṇanti evamādinā bhagavatā
translated: Consciousness is the consciousness category, the consciousness category is consciousness.”

original: paṇṇattivārapavattivārapariññāvārasaṅkhātehi tīhi vārehi vitthārato vibhajitvā desitaṃ.
analyzed: paṇṇatti vāra pavatti vāra pariññā vāra saṅkhātehi tīhi vārehi vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitam
translated: Thus the Blessed One taught the detailed explanation by means of three sections called the section on the definitions, the section on the occurrence, and the section on full understanding.

original: Āyatanayamaka
analyzed: āyatana yamaka
translated: The Compendium on Bases

original: Pucchā – abhidhammapiṭake āvuso chaṭṭhe yamakappakaraṇe tatiyaṃ āyatanayamakaṃ bhagavatā kathaṃ vitthārato vibhajitvā desitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā abhidhammapiṭake āvuso chaṭṭhe yamaka ppakaraṇe tatiyam āyatana yamakam bhagavatā katham vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitam
translated: Question “When, friend, in the sixth Compendium called ‘The Pairs’, in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, the third Compendium of Bases is taught in detail by the Blessed One,🔽how is it taught in detail?🔽Answer “In the sixth Compendium called ‘The Pairs’, in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, the third Compendium of Bases is taught in detail by the Blessed One

original: Vissajjanā – abhidhammapiṭake bhante chaṭṭhe yamakappakaraṇe tatiyaṃ āyatanayamakaṃ
analyzed: vissajjanā abhidhammapiṭake bhante chaṭṭhe yamaka ppakaraṇe tatiyam āyatanayamakam
translated: with the three sections called ‘The Mode of Conveying an Enumeration’, ‘The Mode of Conveying an Occurrence’, and ‘The Mode of Conveying a Full-understanding’,

original: “dvādasāyatanāni – cakkhāyatanaṃ sotāyatanaṃ ghānāyatanaṃ jivhāyatanaṃ kāyāyatanaṃ
analyzed: dvādasa āyatanāni cakkhāyatanam sotāyatanam ghāna āyatanam jivhāyatanam kāyāyatanam
translated: beginning thus: ‘There are twelve bases: the eye base, the ear base, the nose base, the tongue base, the body base,

original: rūpāyatanaṃ saddāyatanaṃ gandhāyatanaṃ rasāyatanaṃ phoṭṭhabbāyatanaṃ manāyatanaṃ🔽dhammāyatanaṃ. Cakkhu cakkhāyatanaṃ, cakkhāyatanaṃ cakkhu. Sotaṃ sotāyatanaṃ, sotāyatanaṃ
analyzed: rūpa āyatanam sadda āyatanam gandha āyatanam rasa āyatanam phoṭṭhabba āyatanam manāyatanam  dhamma āyatanam cakkhu cakkha āyatanam cakkha āyatanam cakkhu sotam sota āyatanam sota āyatanam
translated: the form base, the sound base, the odour base, the flavour base, the tangible-object base, the mind base,

original: sota”nti evamādinā paṇṇattivārapavattivārapariññāvārasaṅkhātehi tīhi vārehi bhagavatā🔽vitthārato vibhajitvā desitaṃ.🔽Dhātuyamaka
analyzed: evamādinā paṇṇatti vāra pavatti vāra pariññā vāra saṅkhātehi tīhi vārehi bhagavatā 🔽vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitam 🔽dhātu yamaka
translated: the mental-object base. The eye is the eye base; the eye base is the eye. The ear is the ear base; the ear base is the ear. The nose is the nose base; the nose base is the nose. The tongue is the tongue base; the tongue base is the tongue. The body is the body base; the body base is the body’ .

original: Pucchā – abhidhammapiṭake āvuso chaṭṭhe yamakappakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu catutthaṃ dhātuyamakaṃ bhagavatā kathaṃ vitthārato vibhajitvā desitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā abhidhammapiṭake āvuso chaṭṭhe yamaka ppakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu catuttham dhātuyamakam bhagavatā katham vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitam
translated: Question: Now, in the sixth Compendium, the Compendium of States, in the ten pairs of questions, how did the Blessed One teach the detailed analysis of the fourth pair of questions, the pair on elements?🔽

original: Vissajjanā – abhidhammapiṭake bhante chaṭṭhe yamakappakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu catutthaṃ🔽dhātuyamakaṃ “aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo – cakkhudhātu sotadhātu ghānadhātu jivhādhātu kāyadhātu🔽rūpadhātu saddadhātu gandhadhātu rasadhātu phoṭṭhabbadhātu cakkhuviññāṇadhātu sotaviññāṇadhātu
analyzed: vissajjanā abhidhammapiṭake bhante chaṭṭhe yamaka pakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu catuttham  dhātu yamakam aṭṭhārasa dhātuyaḥ cakkhu dhātu sota dhātu ghāna dhātu jivhā dhātu kāya dhātu  rūpa dhātu sadda dhātu gandha dhātu rasa dhātu phoṭṭhabba dhātu cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu sota viññāṇa dhātu
translated: Question – In the sixth Compendium, the Pairs, in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, in the ten pairs, how was the fourth pair, the Elements, taught in detail by the Blessed One?

original: ghānaviññāṇadhātu jivhāviññāṇadhātu kāyaviññāṇadhātu manodhātu manoviññāṇadhātu dhammadhātū”ti🔽evamādinā bhagavatā paṇṇattivārapavattivārapariññāvārasaṅkhātehi tīhi mahāvārehi
analyzed: ghāna viññāṇa dhātu jivhā viññāṇa dhātu kāya viññāṇa dhātu manaḥ dhātu manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu dhamma dhātu uti  evamādinā bhagavatā paṇṇatti vāra pavatti vāra pariññā vāra saṅkhātehi tīhi mahāvārehi
translated: Answer – In the sixth Compendium, the Pairs, in the ten pairs, in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, the fourth pair, the Elements, was taught in detail by the Blessed One, beginning thus: “There are eighteen elements: the eye element, the form element, the eye-consciousness element; the ear element, the sound element, the ear-consciousness element; the nose element, the odour element, the nose-consciousness element; the tongue element, the flavour element, the tongue-consciousness element; the body element, the tangible element, the body-consciousness element; the mind element, the mind-object element, the mind-consciousness element.”

original: vitthārato vibhajitvā desitaṃ.
analyzed: vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitam
translated: It was taught in detail by the Blessed One in three great sections called the Section on the Categories, the Section on Occurrence, and the Section on Full-understanding.

original: Saccayamaka
analyzed: sacca yamaka
translated: The Pair on Truth

original: Pucchā – abhidhammapiṭake āvuso chaṭṭhe yamakappakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu pañcamaṃ saccayamakaṃ bhagavatā kathaṃ vitthārato vibhajitvā desitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā abhidhammapiṭake āvuso chaṭṭhe yamaka ppakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu pañcamam saccayamakam bhagavatā katham vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitam
translated: Question “When, friend, in the sixth Compendium called ‘The Pairs’, in the ten pairs, the fifth pair is called ‘The Four Truths’, how was it taught in detail by the Fortunate One?

original: Vissajjanā – abhidhammapiṭake bhante chaṭṭhe yamakappakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu pañcamaṃ
analyzed: vissajjanā abhidhammapiṭake bhante chaṭṭhe yamaka pakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu pañcamam
translated: Answer: “In the sixth Compendium called ‘The Pairs’, in the ten pairs, in the fifth pair called ‘The Four Truths’ in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, the Fortunate One taught in detail:

original: saccayamakaṃ “cattāri saccāni – dukkhasaccaṃ samudayasaccaṃ nirodhasaccaṃ maggasaccaṃ.
analyzed: sacca yamakam cattāri saccāni dukkha saccam samudaya saccam nirodha saccam magga saccam
translated: “There are four truths – the truth of suffering, the truth of arising, the truth of cessation, the truth of the path.

original: Dukkhaṃ dukkhasaccaṃ, dukkhasaccaṃ dukkhaṃ. Samudayo samudayasaccaṃ, samudayasaccaṃ🔽samudayo. Nirodho nirodhasaccaṃ, nirodhasaccaṃ nirodho. Maggo maggasaccaṃ, maggasaccaṃ
analyzed: dukkham dukkha saccam dukkha saccam dukkham samudayaḥ samudaya saccam samudaya saccam  samudayaḥ nirodhaḥ nirodha saccam nirodha saccam nirodhaḥ maggaḥ magga saccam magga saccam
translated: Suffering is the truth of suffering, the truth of suffering is suffering. Arising is the truth of arising, the truth of arising is🔽arising. Cessation is the truth of cessation, the truth of cessation is cessation. The path is the truth of the path, the truth of the path is

original: maggo”ti evamādinā bhagavatā vitthārato vibhajitvā desitaṃ.
analyzed: maggo ti evamādinā bhagavatā vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitam
translated: the path.”

original: Saṅkhārayamaka
analyzed: saṅkhāra yamaka
translated: The Pairs (continued)

original: Pucchā – abhidhammapiṭake āvuso chaṭṭhe yamakappakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu chaṭṭhaṃ saṅkhārayamakaṃ bhagavatā kathaṃ vitthārato vibhajitvā desitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā abhidhammapiṭake āvuso chaṭṭhe yamaka ppakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu chaṭṭham saṅkhārayamakam bhagavatā katham vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitam
translated: Question “In the sixth Compendium, the Compendium of Categories, in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, in the six pairs of questions, in the sixth pair, the Category of Categories, how did the Blessed One teach in detail?”

original: Vissajjanā – abhidhammapiṭake bhante chaṭṭhe yamakappakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu chaṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: vissajjanā abhidhammapiṭake bhante chaṭṭhe yamaka ppakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu chaṭṭham
translated: Answer “In the sixth Compendium, the Compendium of Categories, in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, in the six pairs of questions, in the sixth pair, the Category of Categories, the Blessed One taught in detail in three great divisions called the Mode of Conveying Terms, the Mode of Conveying Occurrences, and the Mode of Conveying Full-understanding.🔽The three categories are the bodily-formation category, the speech-category, and the mental-formation category.

original: saṅkhārayamakaṃ “tayo saṅkhārā – kāyasaṅkhāro vacīsaṅkhāro, cittasaṅkhāro. Assāsapassāsā🔽kāyasaṅkhāro, vitakkavicārā vacīsaṅkhārā, saññā ca vedanā ca cittasaṅkhāro ṭhapetvā
analyzed: saṅkhāra yamakam tayo saṅkhārā kāya saṅkhāraḥ vacī saṅkhāraḥ citta saṅkhāraḥ assāsa passāsā  kāya saṅkhāraḥ vitakka vicārā vacī saṅkhārā saññā ca vedanā ca citta saṅkhāraḥ ṭhapetvā
translated: In-breaths and out-breaths are the bodily-formation category.🔽Applied-thought and sustained-thought are the speech-category.🔽Consciousness and the states associated therewith are the mental-formation category,

original: vitakkavicāre sabbepi cittasampayuttakā dhammā cittasaṅkhāro”ti evamādinā bhagavatā
analyzed: vitakka vicāre sabbe pi citta sampayuttakāḥ dhammāḥ citta saṅkhāro ti evamādinā bhagavatā
translated: except for applied-thought and sustained-thought.

original: paṇṇattivārapavattivārapariññāvārasaṅkhātehi tīhi mahāvārehi vitthārato vibhajitvā desitaṃ.
analyzed: paṇṇatti vāra pavatti vāra pariññā vāra saṅkhātehi tīhi mahāvārehi vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitam
translated: The Blessed One taught in detail in the three great divisions called the Mode of Conveying Terms, the Mode of Conveying Occurrences, and the Mode of Conveying Full-understanding.

original: Anusayayamaka
analyzed: anu saya yamaka
translated: The pair of questions on underlying tendencies

original: Pucchā – abhidhammapiṭake āvuso chaṭṭhe yamakappakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu sattamaṃ anusayayamakaṃ bhagavatā kathaṃ vitthārato vibhajitvā desitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā abhidhammapiṭake āvuso chaṭṭhe yamaka ppakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu sattamam anusaya yamakam bhagavatā katham vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitam
translated: Question: In the sixth Compendium, the Book of Twos, in the ten sections on pairs, the seventh pair is that of underlying tendencies and associatedness. How did the Exalted One teach it in detail?

original: Vissajjanā – abhidhammapiṭake bhante chaṭṭhe yamakappakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu sattamaṃ
analyzed: vissajjanā abhidhammapiṭake bhante chaṭṭhe yamaka ppakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu sattamam
translated: Answer: In the sixth Compendium, the Book of Twos, in the ten sections on pairs, the seventh pair is that of underlying tendencies and associatedness.

original: anusayayamakaṃ “satta anusayā – kāmarāgānusayo paṭighānusayo mānānusayo diṭṭhānusayo
analyzed: anusaya yamakam satta anusayā kāma rāga anusayo paṭigha anusayo māna anusayo diṭṭha anusayo
translated: “There are seven underlying tendencies: the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasure, the underlying tendency to aversion, the underlying tendency to conceit, the underlying tendency to views,

original: vicikicchānusayo bhavarāgānusayo avijjānusayo. Kattha kāmarāgānusayo anuseti, kāmadhātuyā
analyzed: vicikicchā anusayaḥ bhava rāga anusayaḥ avijjā anusayaḥ kattha kāma rāga anusayaḥ anuseti kāmadhātuyā
translated: the underlying tendency to lust for existence, the underlying tendency to ignorance. Where does the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasure underlie?

original: dvīsu vedanāsu ettha kāmarāgānusayo anusetī”ti evamādinā bhagavatā uppattiṭṭhānavāra
analyzed: dvīsu vedanāsu ettha kāma rāga anusayaḥ anuseti iti evamādinā bhagavatā uppatti ṭṭhāna vāra
translated: In the sense-desire element and in two feelings. Here the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasure underlies.” Thus the Exalted One taught in detail the seven underlying tendencies in the eight great sections called the section on the place of origin,

original: anusayavāra sānusayavāra pajahanavāra pariññāvāra pahīnavāra uppajjanavāra dhātuvārasaṅkhātehi🔽aṭṭhahi mahāvārehi vitthārato vibhajitvā desitaṃ.
analyzed: anusaya vāra sa anusaya vāra pajahana vāra pariññā vāra pahīna vāra uppajjana vāra dhātu vāra saṅkhātehi  aṭṭhahi mahāvārehi vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitam
translated: the section on underlying tendencies, the section on associatedness, the section on abandoning, the section on full understanding, the section on abandoning, the section on arising, and the section on elements.

original: Cittayamaka
analyzed: citta yamaka
translated: The Book of Twos

original: Pucchā – abhidhammapiṭake āvuso chaṭṭhe yamakappakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu aṭṭhamaṃ cittayamakaṃ bhagavatā kathaṃ vitthārato vibhajitvā desitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā abhidhammapiṭake āvuso chaṭṭhe yamaka ppakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu aṭṭhamam cittayamakam bhagavatā katham vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitam
translated: Question “When, in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, in the sixth Compendium called the Pairs, in the ten Triads, the eighth triad deals with consciousness, how did the Exalted One teach it in detail?

original: Vissajjanā – abhidhammapiṭake bhante chaṭṭhe yamakappakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu aṭṭhamaṃ🔽cittayamakaṃ “yassa cittaṃ uppajjati na nirujjhati, tassa cittaṃ nirujjhissati na
analyzed: vissajjanā abhidhammapiṭake bhante chaṭṭhe yamaka ppakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu aṭṭhamaṃ  citta yamakam yassa cittam uppajjati na nirujjhati tassa cittam nirujjhissati na
translated: Answer “In the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, venerable sir, in the sixth Compendium called the Pairs, in the ten Triads, the eighth triad deals with consciousness.

original: uppajjissati. Yassa vā pana cittaṃ nirujjhissati na uppajjissati, tassa cittaṃ uppajjati🔽na nirujjhatī”ti evamādinā bhagavatā suddhacittasāmaññasuttantacittamissakavisesaabhidhammacittamissakavisesa-
analyzed: uppajjissati yassa vā pana cittam nirujjhissati na uppajjissati tassa cittam uppajjati  na nirujjhati iti evamādinā bhagavatā
translated: ‘When consciousness arises in a man and does not cease, does his consciousness cease without arising? Or when consciousness ceases in a man and does not arise, does his consciousness arise without ceasing?’

original: saṅkhātehi tīhi mahānayeti vitthārato vibhajitvā desitaṃ.
analyzed: saṅkhātehi tīhi mahānayā iti vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitam
translated: Thus, in the first place, the Exalted One taught it in detail by means of the three great methods called the method of the homogeneousness of consciousness in the Sutta on the homogeneous and heterogeneous , the method of the distinction of consciousness in the Abhidhamma, and the method of the distinction of consciousness in the Abhidhamma.

original: Dhammayamaka
analyzed: dhamma yamaka
translated: The Pairs on Ideas

original: Pucchā – abhidhammapiṭake āvuso chaṭṭhe yamakappakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu navamaṃ dhammayamakaṃ bhagavatā kathaṃ vitthārato vibhajitvā desitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā abhidhammapiṭake āvuso chaṭṭhe yamaka ppakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu navamam dhammayamakam bhagavatā katham vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitam
translated: Question – In the sixth Compendium, the Pairs in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, in the ten pairs, how was the ninth pair, the Pair on Ideas, taught in detail by the Blessed One?

original: Vissajjanā – abhidhammapiṭake bhante chaṭṭhe yamakappakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu navamaṃ🔽dhammayamakaṃ “kusalā kusalā dhammā, kusalā dhammā kusalā. Akusalā akusalā dhammā,
analyzed: vissajjanā abhidhammapiṭake bhante chaṭṭhe yamaka ppakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu navamam  dhamma yamakam kusalā kusalāḥ dhammāḥ kusalāḥ dhammāḥ kusalāḥ akusalāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ
translated: Answer – In the sixth Compendium, the Pairs in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, in the ten pairs, the ninth pair,

original: akusalā dhammā akusalā. Abyākatā abyākatā dhammā, abyākatā dhammā abyākatā”ti evamādinā
analyzed: akusalāḥ dhammāḥ akusalāḥ abyākatāḥ abyākatāḥ dhammāḥ abyākatāḥ dhammāḥ abyākatā ati evamādinā
translated: the Pair on Ideas, was taught in detail by the Blessed One thus: “ Ideas that are wholesome are ideas that are wholesome. Ideas that are unwholesome are ideas that are unwholesome. Ideas that are indeterminate are ideas that are indeterminate” ,

original: bhagavatā paṇṇattivārapavattivārapariññāvārasaṅkhātehi tīhi mahāvārehi vitthārato vibhajitvā desitaṃ.
analyzed: bhagavatā paṇṇatti vāra pavatti vāra pariññā vāra saṅkhātehi tīhi mahāvārehi vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitam
translated: and so on, in the three great divisions called the Mode of Conveying Terms, the Mode of Conveying Occurrences, and the Mode of Conveying Full-understanding.

original: Indriyayamaka
analyzed: indriya yamaka
translated: The Pair on Faculties

original: Pucchā – abhidhammapiṭake āvuso chaṭṭhe yamakappakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu dasamaṃ indriyayamakaṃ bhagavatā kathaṃ vitthārato vibhajitvā desitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā abhidhammapiṭake āvuso chaṭṭhe yamaka ppakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu dasamam indriya yamakam bhagavatā katham vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitam
translated: Question – In the sixth Compendium, the Pairs in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, in the ten pairs, how was the tenth pair, the Pair on Faculties, taught in detail by the Blessed One?

original: Vissajjanā – abhidhammapiṭake bhante chaṭṭhe yamakappakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu dasamaṃ
analyzed: vissajjanā abhidhammapiṭake bhante chaṭṭhe yamaka ppakaraṇe dasasu yamakesu dasamam
translated: The explanation is that given in the sixth Compendium, the Compendium of Discourses, in the ten pairs of questions, the tenth pair,

original: indriyayamakaṃ “bāvīsatindriyāni – cakkhundriyaṃ sotindriyaṃ ghānindriyaṃ jivhindriyaṃ
analyzed: indriya yamakam bāvīsati indriyāni cakkhu indriyam sotindriyam ghānindriyam jivhindriyam
translated: the pair on faculties, which is as follows: “There are twenty-two faculties: the eye faculty, the ear faculty, the nose faculty, the tongue faculty,

original: kāyindriyaṃ itthindriyaṃ purisindriyaṃ jīvitindriyaṃ manindriyaṃ sukhindriyaṃ dukkhindriyaṃ
analyzed: kāya indriyam itthi indriyam purisa indriyam jīvita indriyam manindriyam sukha indriyam dukkha indriyam
translated: the body faculty, the femininity faculty, the masculinity faculty, the life faculty, the mind faculty, the pleasure faculty, the pain faculty,

original: somanassindriyaṃ domanassindriyaṃ upekkhindriyaṃ saddhindriyaṃ vīriyindriyaṃ samādhindriyaṃ
analyzed: somanassa indriyam domanassa indriyam upekkhindriyam saddhindriyam vīriyindriyam samādhindriyam
translated: the joy faculty, the grief faculty, the equanimity faculty, the faith faculty, the energy faculty, the mindfulness faculty,

original: paññindriyaṃ anaññātaññassāmītindriyaṃ aññindriyaṃ aññātāvindriya”nti evamādinā bhagavatā
analyzed: paññindriyam evamādinā bhagavatā
translated: the concentration faculty, the understanding faculty, the I-shall-come-to-know-the-unknown faculty, the final-knowledge faculty, the final-knower faculty” .

original: paṇṇattivāra pavattivāra pariññāvārasaṅkhātehi tīhi mahāvārehi vitthārato vibhajitvā desitaṃ.
analyzed: paṇṇatti vāra pavatti vāra pariññā vāra saṅkhātehi tīhi mahāvārehi vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitam
translated: This is taught in detail in the three great divisions called the “Enumeration Section,” the “Occurrence Section,” and the “Full-Understanding Section.”

original: Atītavāra
analyzed: atītavāra
translated: The past section

original: Pucchā – abhidhammapiṭake āvuso indriyayamake tīsu mahāvāresu pavattivāre uppādaatītavāro bhagavatā kathaṃ vitthārena vibhajitvā desito.
analyzed: pucchā abhidhammapiṭake āvuso indriya yamake tīsu mahāvāresu pavatti vāre uppāda atīta vāraḥ bhagavatā katham vitthārena vibhajitvā desitaḥ
translated: Question 1. How did the Blessed One explain in detail the past section on the arising of the faculties in the occurrence section in the three great divisions in the Compendium of Discourses on the faculties?

original: Vissajjanā – abhidhammapiṭake bhante indriyayamake tīsu mahāvāresu pavattivāre uppādaatītavāro
analyzed: vissajjanā abhidhammapiṭake bhante indriya yamake tīsu mahāvāresu pavatti vāre uppāda atīta vāro
translated: The ‘relinquishment’ is the ‘arising-past-non-arising’ round in the three great method-rounds in the Abhidhamma-Piṭaka in the ‘Indriya-Yamaka’ .

original: “yassa cakkhundriyaṃ uppajjitta, tassa sotindriyaṃ, ghānindriyaṃ, jivhindriyaṃ, kāyindriyaṃ,
analyzed: yassa cakkhu indriyam uppajjitta tassa sotindriyam ghānindriyam jivhindriyam kāyindriyam
translated: ‘When the eye faculty has arisen in him, has the ear faculty … the nose faculty … the tongue faculty … the body faculty …

original: itthindriyaṃ, purisindriyaṃ, jīvitindriyaṃ, somanassindriyaṃ, upekkhindriyaṃ, saddhindriyaṃ,
analyzed: itthi indriyam purisa indriyam jīvitindriyam somanassindriyam upekkhindriyam saddhindriyam
translated: the femininity faculty … the masculinity faculty … the life faculty … the joy faculty … the equanimity faculty … the faith faculty …

original: vīriyindriyaṃ, satindriyaṃ, samādhindriyaṃ, paññindriyaṃ, manindriyaṃ, uppajjitthāti,
analyzed: vīriya indriyam sati indriyam samādhi indriyam paññindriyam manindriyam uppajjittha ati
translated: the energy faculty … the mindfulness faculty … the concentration faculty … the understanding faculty … the mind faculty … arisen in him?🔽‘Yes, friend. ‘

original: āmantā. Yassa vā pana manindriyaṃ uppajjittha, tassa cakkhundriyaṃ uppajjitthāti,
analyzed: āmantā yassa vā pana man indriyam uppajjittha tassa cakkhu indriyam uppajjittha ati
translated: ‘Or when the mind faculty has arisen in him, has the eye faculty arisen in him?🔽‘Yes, friend.’

original: āmantā”ti evamādinā bhagavatā vibhajitvā desito.
analyzed: āmantā ati evamādinā bhagavatā vibhajitvā desitaḥ
translated: The Blessed One taught it after analysing it thus.

original: Uppādaanāgatavāra
analyzed: uppāda anāgata vāra
translated: The ‘arising-future-non-arising’ round

original: Pucchā – abhidhammapiṭake āvuso indriyayamake tīsu mahāvāresu pavattivāre uppādaanāgatavāro bhagavatā kathaṃ vitthārena vibhajitvā desito.
analyzed: pucchā abhidhammapiṭake āvuso indriya yamake tīsu mahāvāresu pavatti vāre uppāda anāgata vāraḥ bhagavatā katham vitthārena vibhajitvā desitaḥ
translated: ‘Question: Friend, how did the Blessed One teach the ‘arising-future-non-arising’ round in the three great method-rounds in the ‘Indriya-Yamaka’ in the Abhidhamma-Piṭaka in detail after analysing it?

original: Vissajjanā – abhidhammapiṭake bhante indriyayamake tīsu mahāvāresu pavattivāre uppādaanāgatavāro🔽“yassa cakkhundriyaṃ uppajjissati, tassa sotindriyaṃ uppajjissatīti, āmantā. Yassa🔽vā pana sotindriyaṃ uppajjissati, tassa cakkhundriyaṃ uppajjissatī”ti āmantā. Yassa🔽cakkhundriyaṃ uppajjissati, tassa ghānindriyaṃ, jivhindriyaṃ, kāyindriyaṃ uppajjissatīti,
analyzed: vissajjanā abhidhammapiṭake bhante indriya yamake tīsu mahāvāresu pavatti vāre uppāda anāgata vāro  yassa cakkhu indriyam uppajjissati tassa sotindriyam uppajjissati iti āmantā yassa  vā pana sotindriyam uppajjissati tassa cakkhundriyam uppajjissati iti āmantā yassa  cakkhu indriyam uppajjissati tassa ghāna indriyam jivhindriyam kāyindriyam uppajjissati iti
translated: The answer is in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, in the Indriya Mātikā, in the three great sections, in the section on the arising of the faculties in the future.🔽“If the eye faculty arises in him, will the ear faculty arise in him? Yes, venerable sir.🔽Or if the ear faculty will arise in him, will the eye faculty arise in him? Yes, venerable sir.🔽If the eye faculty arises in him, will the nose faculty, the tongue faculty, and the body faculty arise in him?

original: ye rūpāvacaraṃ upapajjitvā parinibbāyissanti, tesaṃ cakkhundriyaṃ uppajjissati, no🔽ca tesaṃ kāyindriyaṃ uppajjissati, itaresaṃ tesaṃ cakkhundriyañca uppajjissati kāyindriyañca🔽uppajjissatī”ti evamādinā bhagavatā vitthārato vibhajitvā desito.🔽Yassa cakkhundriyaṃ uppajjissati, tassa itthindriyaṃ uppajjissatīti. Ye rūpāvacaraṃ
analyzed: ye rūpāvacaram upapajjitvā parinibbāyissanti tesam cakkhu indriyam uppajjissati no 🔽ca tesam kāya indriyam uppajjissati itaresam tesam cakkhundriyam ca uppajjissati kāya indriyam ca 🔽uppajjissati iti evamādinā bhagavatā vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā desitaḥ 🔽yassa cakkhu indriyam uppajjissati tassa itthi indriyam uppajjissati iti ye rūpāvacaram
translated: The ‘releasing’ is that taught in detail by the Blessed One in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka in the Indriya Kanda in the three great divisions in the section on the ‘mode of Conveying a Conversion’ in the ‘mode of Conveying a Conversion Dealing with Arising in the Future’ thus: ‘When the eye faculty arises in him, does the ear faculty arise in him? ‘ ‘Yes, Lord’. ‘Or when the ear faculty arises in him, does the eye faculty arise in him? ‘ ‘Yes, Lord’. ‘When the eye faculty arises in him, does the nose faculty … does the tongue faculty … does the body faculty arise in him? ‘ ‘Yes, Lord’. ‘When the body faculty arises in him, does the eye faculty arise in him? ‘ ‘Yes, Lord’. ‘Or when the eye faculty arises in him, does the body faculty arise in him? ‘ ‘Yes, Lord’. ‘When the eye faculty arises in him, does the ear faculty … does the nose faculty … does the tongue faculty … does the body faculty arise in him? ‘ ‘Yes, Lord’. ‘When the body faculty arises in him, does the eye faculty arise in him? ‘ ‘Yes, Lord’. ‘Or when the eye faculty arises in him, does the body faculty arise in him? ‘ ‘Yes, Lord’. ‘When the eye faculty arises in him, does the femininity faculty arise in him? ‘ ‘Yes, Lord’. ‘Or when the femininity faculty arises in him, does the eye faculty arise in him? ‘ ‘Yes, Lord’. ‘When the eye faculty arises in him, does the masculinity faculty arise in him? ‘ ‘Yes, Lord’. ‘Or when the masculinity faculty arises in him, does the eye faculty arise in him? ‘ ‘Yes, Lord’. ‘When the eye faculty arises in him, does the femininity faculty arise in him? ‘ ‘Yes, Lord’. ‘Or when the femininity faculty arises in him, does the eye faculty arise in him? ‘ ‘Yes, Lord’.

original: upapajjitvā parinibbāyissanti, ye ca purisā eteneva bhāvena katici bhave dassetvā
analyzed: upapajjitvā parinibbāyissanti ye ca purisāḥ etena iva bhāvena katici bhave dassetvā
translated: and those men who, after manifesting this state for a few existences,

original: parinibbāyissanti tesaṃ cakkhundriyaṃ uppajjissati, no ca tesaṃ itthindriyaṃ uppajjissati,
analyzed: parinibbāyissanti tesam cakkhu indriyam uppajjissati no ca tesam itthi indriyam uppajjissati
translated: will attain final Nibbāna, for them the eye faculty will arise, but not the female faculty.

original: itaresaṃ tesaṃ cakkhundriyañca uppajjissati itthindriyañca uppajjissati.
analyzed: itaresam tesam cakkhu indriyam ca uppajjissati itthi indriyam ca uppajjissati
translated: For the rest, for them both the eye faculty and the female faculty will arise.

original: Yassa cakkhundriyaṃ uppajjissati, tassa purisindriyaṃ uppajjissatīti, ye rūpāvacaraṃ
analyzed: yassa cakkhu indriyam uppajjissati tassa purisa indriyam uppajjissati iti ye rūpāvacaram
translated: “Those in whom the eye faculty will arise, will the male faculty arise in them?” Those who will be reborn in the fine-material sphere,

original: upapajjitvā parinibbāyissanti, yā ca itthiyo eteneva bhāvena katici bhave dassetvā
analyzed: upapajjitvā parinibbāyissanti yā ca itthiyo etena iva bhāvena katici bhave dassetvā
translated: and those women who, after manifesting this state for a few existences,

original: parinibbāyissanti, tesaṃ cakkhundriyaṃ uppajjissati, no ca tesaṃ purisindriyaṃ uppajjissati.
analyzed: parinibbāyissanti tesam cakkhu indriyam uppajjissati no ca tesam purisa indriyam uppajjissati
translated: will attain final Nibbāna, for them the eye faculty will arise, but not the male faculty.

original: Itaresaṃ tesaṃ cakkhundriyañca uppajjissati purisindriyañca uppajjissati.
analyzed: itaresam tesam cakkhu indriyam ca uppajjissati purisa indriyam ca uppajjissati
translated: For the rest, for them both the eye faculty and the male faculty will arise.

original: Yassa itthindriyaṃ uppajjissati, tassa purisindriyaṃ uppajjissatīti, yā itthiyo eteneva
analyzed: yassa itthi indriyam uppajjissati tassa purisa indriyam uppajjissati iti yā itthiyā etena iva
translated: “Those in whom the female faculty will arise, will the male faculty arise in them?” Those women who, after manifesting this state for a few existences,

original: bhāvena katici bhave dassetvā parinibbāyissanti, tāsaṃ itthindriyaṃ uppajjissati,
analyzed: bhāvena katici bhave dassetvā parinibbāyissanti tāsam itthi indriyam uppajjissati
translated: and after showing the way in the world for a while, will attain final Nibbāna, for them the female faculty will arise,

original: no ca tāsaṃ purisindriyaṃ uppajjissati. Itaresaṃ tesaṃ itthindriyañca uppajjissati
analyzed: no ca tāsam purisa indriyam uppajjissati itaresam tesam itthi indriyam ca uppajjissati
translated: but for them the male faculty will not arise. For the rest of them the female faculty will arise,

original: purisindriyañca uppajjissati.
analyzed: purisa indriyañca uppajjissati
translated: and the male faculty will arise.

original: Paṭṭhāna
analyzed: paṭṭhāna
translated: The Puggala Paññatti🔽Question: – By the Blessed One, friend, who knows, who sees, accomplished and fully enlightened,

original: Pucchā – tenāvuso bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena abhisambuddhakālato
analyzed: pucchā tena āvuso bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena abhisambuddha kālataḥ
translated: after the attainment of Buddhahood,

original: sattamavasse manussaloke yamakapāṭihīraṃ dassetvā tadanantaraṃ tāvatiṃsadevalokaṃ🔽gantvā tattha paṇḍukambalasilāyaṃ sannisīditvā dasahi cakkavāḷasahassehi āgamma sannisinnānaṃ
analyzed: sattama vasse manussa loke yamaka pāṭihīram dassetvā tad anantaram tāvatiṃsa deva lokam  gantvā tattha paṇḍukambala silāyam sannisīditvā dasahi cakkavāḷa sahassehi āgamma sannisinnānam
translated: after showing the Twin Miracle in the world of men in the seventh year, after that, having gone to the world of the Thirty-three Gods,🔽after sitting down on the coral-tree stone there, after teaching the Abhidhamma to the gods who had come from ten thousand world systems and had sat down,

original: devānaṃ abhidhammadesanaṃ desentena yāva yamakappakaraṇā purimāni cha abhidhammappakaraṇāni
analyzed: devānam abhidhamma desanam desentena yāva yamaka ppakaraṇā purimāni cha abhidhamma ppakaraṇāni
translated: after teaching the first six Abhidhamma Piṭaka from the time of the Twin Miracle,

original: desetvā tadanantaraṃ kiṃnāma pakaraṇaṃ desitaṃ.
analyzed: desetvā tad anantaram kiṃnāma pakaraṇam desitam
translated: after that, what Piṭaka was taught?

original: Vissajjanā – tena bhante bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena abhisambuddhakālato
analyzed: vissajjanā tena bhante bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena abhisambuddha kālataḥ
translated: The answer is: From the time of the Blessed One’s enlightenment

original: sattame vasse manussaloke sāvatthiyaṃ kaṇḍambamūle yamakapāṭihīraṃ dassetvā tadanantaraṃ🔽tāvatiṃsadevalokaṃ gantvā tattha paṇḍukambalasilāyaṃ sannipatitvā dasahi cakkavāḷasahassehi
analyzed: sattame vasse manussa loke sāvatthiyam kaṇḍamba mūle yamaka pāṭihīram dassetvā tad anantaram  tāvatiṃsa deva lokam gantvā tattha paṇḍukambala silāyam sannipatitvā dasahi cakkavāḷa sahassehi
translated: in the seventh year, in the human world, at Sāvatthī, at the root of the Kaṇḍamba Tree, he had shown the Twin Miracle,🔽and then he had gone to the Tāvatiṃsa World of the Gods and there, on the Marble-slab Seat, he had taught the Abhidhamma to the assembled deities who had come from ten thousand world-systems.

original: āgamma sannisinnānaṃ devānaṃ abhidhammadesanaṃ desentena purimāni cha abhidhammappakaraṇāni
analyzed: āgamma sannisinnānam devānam abhidhamma desanam desentena purimāni cha abhidhamma ppakaraṇāni
translated: After teaching the first six Abhidhamma Piṭaka-texts

original: desetvā tadanantaraṃ anantanayasamantapaṭṭhānaṃ nāma sattamaṃ mahāpakaraṇaṃ desitaṃ.
analyzed: desetvā tad anantaram anantanayasamantapaṭṭhānam nāma sattamam mahā pakaraṇam desitam
translated: he then taught the seventh great text called the Patthāna.

original: Pucchā – taṃ panetaṃ āvuso paṭṭhānaṃ kenaṭṭhena paṭṭhānanti vuccati.
analyzed: pucchā tam pana itam āvuso paṭṭhānam kenaṭṭhena paṭṭhānanti vuccati
translated: Question 1: But, friend, why is that called the Patthāna?

original: Vissajjanā – taṃ panetaṃ bhante paṭṭhānaṃ nānappakārapaccayaṭṭhena vibhajanaṭṭhena paṭṭhitaṭṭhena ca paṭṭhānanti vuccati.
analyzed: vissajjanā tat pana itam bhante paṭṭhānam nānappakāra paccaya ṭṭhena vibhajana ṭṭhena paṭṭhita ṭṭhena ca paṭṭhānam ti vuccati
translated: Answer: That is called the Patthāna, venerable sir, because of the various kinds of conditions, because of the analysis, and because of the establishment .

original: Pucchā – tañcāvuso bhagavatā paṭṭhānamahāpakaraṇaṃ desentena katihi vārehi vibhajitvā desitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā tat ca āvuso bhagavatā paṭṭhāna mahā apakaraṇam desentena katihi vārehi vibhajitvā desitam
translated: Question – And when the Blessed One was teaching the Great Book on Causation, in how many sections did he divide it and teach it?

original: Vissajjanā – taṃ kho bhante bhagavatā paṭṭhānamahāpakaraṇaṃ desentena mātikānikkhepavārasaṅkhāto paccayuddeso paccayaniddeso mahāvāreti dvīhi paricchedavārehi vibhajitvā desitaṃ.
analyzed: vissajjanā tam kho bhante bhagavatā paṭṭhāna mahā pakaraṇam desentena mātikā nikkhepa vāra saṅkhātaḥ paccayuddeso paccaya niddeso mahāvāra iti dvīhi pariccheda vārehi vibhajitvā desitam
translated: Answer – When the Blessed One was teaching the Great Book on Causation, he divided it into two sections and taught it, namely, the Description of the Requisite Conditions, called the Setting Forth of the Matrix, and the Description of the Conditions, called the Great Book.

original: Pucchā – tesu āvuso vāresu paṭhame mātikānikkhepavāre paccayuddesavāro bhagavatā kathaṃ desito.
analyzed: pucchā tesu āvuso vāresu paṭhame mātikā nikkhepa vāre paccayuddesa vāraḥ bhagavatā katham desito
translated: Question – And how did the Blessed One teach the Description of the Requisite Conditions in the first section, the Setting Forth of the Matrix?

original: Vissajjanā – tesu bhante dvīsu paricchedavāresu paṭhame mātikānikkhepavāre paccayuddese🔽hetupaccayo ārammaṇapaccayo adhipatipaccayo anantarapaccayo samanantarapaccayo sahajātapaccayo
analyzed: vissajjanā tesu bhante dvīsu pariccheda vāresu paṭhame mātikā nikkhepa vāre paccaya uddese  hetu paccayaḥ ārammaṇa paccayaḥ adhipati paccayaḥ anantara paccayaḥ samanantara paccayaḥ sahajāta paccayaḥ
translated: Answer – In the first section, the Description of the Requisite Conditions,🔽he taught thus: “There are these six kinds of requisite conditions, namely, root-cause condition, object condition, predominance condition, proximity condition, contiguity condition, and arising-together condition.

original: aññamaññapaccayo nissayapaccayo…pe… avigatapaccayo”ti. Evaṃ kho bhante bhagavatā vibhajitvā desito.
analyzed: aññamañña paccayaḥ nissaya paccaya upe avigata paccayaḥ ti evam kho bhante bhagavatā vibhajitvā desitaḥ
translated: There are these six kinds of requisite conditions, namely, mutuality condition, support condition, … absence condition” . Thus the Blessed One taught it after dividing it.

original: Pucchā – tadanantaraṃ pana āvuso paccayaniddesavāro bhagavatā kathaṃ vibhajitvā desito.🔽Vissajjanā – tadanantaraṃ pana bhante paccayaniddesavāro “hetupaccayoti – hetū hetusampayuttakānaṃ
analyzed: pucchā tad anantaram pana āvuso paccaya niddesa vāraḥ bhagavatā katham vibhajitvā desitaḥ  vissajjanā tad anantaram pana bhante paccaya niddesa vāraḥ hetu paccayaḥ ti hetū hetu sampayuttakānam
translated: Question: But, friend, how did the Blessed One analyse and teach the section on the description of conditions that comes next?

original: dhammānaṃ taṃsamuṭṭhānānañca rūpānaṃ hetupaccayena paccayo. Ārammaṇapaccayoti – rūpārammaṇaṃ🔽cakkhuviññāṇadhātuyā taṃsampayuttakānañca dhammānaṃ ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo. Saddhāyatanaṃ🔽sotaviññāṇadhātuyā…. Gandhāyatanaṃ ghānaviññāṇadhātuyā…. Rasāyatanaṃ jivhāviññāṇadhātuyā….🔽Phoṭṭhabbāyatanaṃ kāyaviññāṇadhātuyā taṃsampayuttakānañca dhammānaṃ ārammaṇapaccayena
analyzed: dhammānam tad samuṭṭhānānaṃ ca rūpānaṃ hetu paccayena paccayaḥ ārammaṇa paccayo ti rūpa ārammaṇam  cakkhu viññāṇa dhātuyā tad sampayuttakānaṃ ca dhammānaṃ ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ saddhā āyatanam  sota viññāṇa dhātuyāḥ gandha āyatanam ghāna viññāṇa dhātuyāḥ rasa āyatanam jivhā viññāṇa dhātuyāḥ  phoṭṭhabba āyatanam kāya viññāṇa dhātuyā tad sampayuttakānaṃ ca dhammānam ārammaṇa paccayena
translated: Reply: But, venerable sir, the section on the description of conditions that comes next was analysed and taught by the Blessed One thus: “As to ‘root condition’: roots are a condition for what is associated with them🔽by root condition. As to ‘object condition’: the form base is a condition for the eye-consciousness element and for the states associated therewith by object condition. The sound base is a condition for the ear-consciousness element … The odour base is a condition for the nose-consciousness element … The flavour base is a condition for the tongue-consciousness element …

original: paccayo. Rūpāyatanaṃ saddāyatanaṃ gandhāyatanaṃ rasāyatanaṃ phoṭṭhabbāyatanaṃ manodhātuyā
analyzed: paccayaḥ rūpa āyatanam sadda āyatanam gandha āyatanam rasa āyatanam phoṭṭhabba āyatanam manas dhātuyāḥ
translated: The tangible-data base is a condition for the body-consciousness element and for the states associated therewith by object condition. The form base, the sound base, the odour base, the flavour base, the tangible-data base are a condition for the mind element

original: taṃsampayuttakānañca dhammānaṃ ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo. Sabbe dhammā manoviññāṇadhātuyā🔽taṃsampayuttakānañca dhammānaṃ ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo. Yaṃ yaṃ dhammaṃ ārabbha
analyzed: tad sampayuttakānaṃ ca dhammānaṃ ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ sabbe dhammā manas viññāṇa dhātuyā  tad sampayuttakānaṃ ca dhammānam ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ yam yam dhammaṃ ārabbha
translated: and are a condition, as object condition, for the states associated with it. All states are a condition, as object condition, for the mind-consciousness element🔽and for the states associated with it. Whatever states arise in dependence on a particular state,

original: ye ye dhammā uppajjanti cittacetasikā dhammā, te te dhammā tesaṃ tesaṃ dhammānaṃ
analyzed: ye ye dhammā uppajjanti citta cetasikāḥ dhammāḥ te te dhammāḥ tesam tesam dhammānam
translated: those states are a condition, as object condition, for that particular state.

original: ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo”ti evamādinā bhagavatā vibhajitvā desito.🔽Pucchā – tenāvuso…pe… sammāsambuddhena abhidhammapiṭake sattame mahāpakaraṇe dvīsu padhānavāresu dutiye mahāvāre kati ṭhānāni vibhajitvā desitāni.
analyzed: ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ ti evamādinā bhagavatā vibhajitvā desitaḥ  pucchā tena āvuso upe sammāsambuddhena abhidhammapiṭake sattame mahā apakaraṇe dvīsu padhāna vāresu dutiye mahāvāre kati ṭhānāni vibhajitvā desitāni
translated: Thus it was in sections that the Blessed One explained the object condition.”🔽“How many instances of the establishment of mindfulness were explained by the Blessed One who knows and sees, accomplished and fully enlightened, it was asked, and how many instances of the establishment of mindfulness were explained by the Blessed One who knows and sees, accomplished and fully enlightened, in what way?

original: Vissajjanā – abhidhammapiṭake bhante sattasu pakaraṇesu sattame anantanayasamantapaṭṭhāne
analyzed: vissajjanā abhidhammapiṭake bhante sattasu pakaraṇesu sattame ananta naya samanta paṭṭhāne
translated: “In the seventh great division of the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, in the two great sections, in the second great section, in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, venerable sir, in the seventh great division, in the section on the endless modes of progress,

original: mahāpakaraṇe dvīsu padhānaparicchedavāresu dutiye mahāvāre dhammānulome cha paṭṭhānāni,
analyzed: mahāpakaraṇe dvīsu padhāna pariccheda vāresu dutiye mahāvāre dhamma anulome cha paṭṭhānāni
translated: in the great book, in the two great sections, in the second great section, in the forward order, there are six instances of the establishment of mindfulness,

original: tathā dhammapaccanīye dhammānulomapaccanīye dhammapaccanīyānulometi catuvīsati paṭṭhānāni
analyzed: tathā dhamma paccanīye dhamma anuloma paccanīye dhamma paccanīya anulomā iti catuvīsati paṭṭhānāni
translated: Likewise, in the case of the opposites of ideas, in the case of the opposites of ideas in conformity with the ideas, in the case of the opposites of ideas in conformity with the opposites of ideas, there are twenty-four Modes.

original: bhagavatā vibhajitvā desitāni.
analyzed: bhagavatā vibhajitvā desitāni
translated: These were analysed and taught by the Blessed One.

original: Dhammānuloma tikapaṭṭhāna
analyzed: dhamma anuloma tika paṭṭhāna
translated: The Conformity with Ideas in Triads

original: Pucchā – tesupi āvuso catuvīsatiyā paṭṭhānesu paṭhame dhammānulomatikapaṭṭhāne dvāvīsatitikā bhagavatā katihi vārehi vibhajitvā desitā.
analyzed: pucchā tesu pi āvuso catuvīsatiyā paṭṭhānesu paṭhame dhamma anulomatika paṭṭhāne dvāvīsatitikā bhagavatā katihi vārehi vibhajitvā desitā
translated: Question: But, friend, in the case of these twenty-four Modes, in the first Mode, that in conformity with ideas in triads, how many times did the Blessed One analyse the twenty-two triads and teach them?

original: Vissajjanā – tesu bhante catuvīsatiyā mahāpaṭṭhānesu paṭhame dhammānulomatikapaṭṭhāne
analyzed: vissajjanā tesu bhante catuvīsatiyā mahā paṭṭhānesu paṭhame dhamma anulomatika paṭṭhāne
translated: Answer: In the case of these twenty-four great Modes, in the first Mode, that in conformity with ideas in triads,

original: dvāvīsatitikā paṭiccavāro sahajātavāro paccayavāro nissayavāro saṃsaṭṭhavāro sampayuttavāro
analyzed: dvāvīsatitikā paṭiccavāro sahajāta vāro paccayavāro nissayavāro saṃsaṭṭhavāro sampayuttavāro
translated: the Dependence class, the Conascence class, the Root-Cause class, the Support class, the Associated class, the Related class,

original: pañhāvāroti sattahi sattahi vārehi vibhajitvā bhagavatā desitā.
analyzed: pañhāvāro ti sattahi sattahi vārehi vibhajitvā bhagavatā desitā
translated: and the Question class, were analysed and taught by the Blessed One in seven times seven ways.

original: Kusalatika paṭiccavāra
analyzed: kusalatika paṭiccavāra
translated: The Dependence Class in the Wholesome Triad

original: Pucchā – tesu cāvuso dvāvīsatiyā tikesu paṭhame kusalattike sattasu mahāvāresu paṭhamo paṭiccamahāvāro bhagavatā kathaṃ vibhajitvā desito.
analyzed: pucchā tesu ca āvuso dvāvīsatiyā tikesu paṭhame kusala ttike sattasu mahāvāresu paṭhamaḥ paṭiccamahāvāraḥ bhagavatā katham vibhajitvā desito
translated: Question: But, friend, in the case of these twenty-two triads, in the first wholesome triad, how did the Blessed One analyse the first Dependence class in the seven great classes?

original: Vissajjanā – tesu bhante dvāvīsatiyā tikesu paṭhame kusalattike sattasu mahāvāresu

translated: In the case of the three wholesome roots, in the seven great divisions, the third section on conditions is as follows: “It may be that a wholesome state, as condition,🔽precedes a wholesome state by way of root condition. It may be that a wholesome state, as condition, precedes an unwholesome state …🔽It may be that a wholesome state, as condition, precedes an indeterminate state …🔽by way of root condition.” The answer section is as follows: “A wholesome state, as condition, precedes a wholesome state by way of root condition. A single aggregate is the condition, by way of root condition, for three aggregates. Three aggregates are the condition, by way of root condition, for a single aggregate. Two aggregates are the condition, by way of root condition, for two aggregates.” “In the case of root condition, there are seventeen. In the case of object condition, there are seven. In the case of predominance condition, there are seventeen. In the case of proximity condition, there are seven. In the case of contiguity condition, there are seven. In the case of conascence condition, there are seven.

Conditioned by one profitable aggregate there is occasion for three aggregates, conditioned by three aggregates there is occasion for one aggregate, conditioned by two aggregates there is occasion for two aggregates” , and so on with the answers, and that beginning thus: “By root-cause seventeen, by object seven, by predominance seventeen, by proximity and by contiguity seven, by kamma seven, by nutriment seventeen, by faculty seventeen, by jhana seventeen, by path seventeen, by association seven, by non-disappearance seventeen” , and so on with the enumeration.
